post.author: natgeo
post.title: Photo by Charlie Hamilton James | @chamiltonjames A giant otter, known by local scientists as Two Spot, munches on a fish on Cocha Salvador, an oxbow lake in Manú National Park, in Peru. Giant otters are, well, giant—reaching lengths of up to 6 feet and weighing up to 75 pounds. Giant otters are rare across much of South America as they require pretty niche habitat, but they thrive in Manú because of the number of fish-rich lakes. These otters are social and rarely seen alone. More often that not, they go around in family groups; I once counted 15 in one group. Being in a large family helps protect them against predators such as caimans and jaguars.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Photos by @timlaman | The Vogelkop superb bird of paradise has one of the bird world’s most striking displays: its fake blue eyespots and bright breast shield are set against a black cape. Swipe to see what the bird looks like when calling from a tree with its cape down, and then spreading and raising its cape to dance for a female that visits the male’s display log.  Photographed in the Arfak Mountains of West Papua, Indonesia. See the video at @timlaman. #superbbirdofparadise #birdofparadise #Indonesia #papua #birds #courtship

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Photo and video by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo | Believe it or not, this large brown bear is actually a male American black bear that has settled into an abandoned home in South Lake Tahoe, California. For my new feature in National Geographic magazine’s July issue, I followed urban ecologists and wildlife experts across the United States in search of bears, raccoons, and coyotes that have uniquely adapted to life in dense urban settings. This bear slept under this home most days, and like clockwork every night after dark, he would balloon out of the crawl space and scour the neighborhood for unattended garbage. Read the full story at the link in bio and follow the behind-the-scenes look at my urban wildlife project at @arni_coraldo.  #bear #urbanwildlife #southlaketahoe #blackbear #cameratrap

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Photo by @javier_aznar_photography | The naked man orchid (Orchis italica) is a beauty whose name speaks for itself. Native to the Mediterranean Basin, this orchid was photographed in Castilla la Mancha, Spain. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to see more orchids. #flower #orchid #Spain

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @bertiegregory | A lioness and her cub rest after a long day dealing with pride politics. This mother had only recently introduced her new cubs to the rest of the pride. While most of the adults accepted them without issue, two of the larger juveniles in the pride had shown a little too much interest. They'd wait for the mother to get distracted before coming over to mess with the little cubs. The mother would soon come charging over. Growling, snarling, and some boxing solved the problem. Filmed in Zambia’s South Luangwa National Park for my new show, coming later this year to @disneyplus. #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Happy H-OWL-oween from the owls of @joelsartore’s Photo Ark!

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Photos by Charlie Hamilton James @chamiltonjames, words by National Geographic Explorer @paula_kahumbu | Nothing can prepare you for the sight and smell of so many dead wildebeests, zebras, elephants, giraffes, cattle, and sheep that are littering the barren landscape of southern Kenya’s Kajiado County. These catastrophic deaths come after 18 months without rain, the result of three failed rainy seasons. The low rainfall isn’t new, but it is the first time such extreme losses have been recorded. Interacting factors, such as climate change and overstocking of livestock, have made the land far less productive and far more vulnerable to shocks like drought. Though there’s water to drink, there’s not a blade of grass. Rains in the past week have slightly improved conditions, but unless they persist the problem will continue to worsen. With support from the National Geographic Society @insidenatgeo.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @jason_gulley_science and @gena.g.steffens | Manatees—often called sea cows—are “charismatic” wild animals that hold humans in their thrall. Neither predator nor prey, these peaceable creatures, which can grow to 13 feet and weigh more than 2,000 pounds, are evolutionarily devoid of aggression. Read the full story at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Watching this mother polar bear and her two cubs descend slippery coastal cliffs in Norway's Svalbard archipelago during a blizzard was nothing short of impressive. These animals are deserving of the title apex predator; with agility on steep rock and slippery ice and in the water, polar bears are in a class of their own. Filmed in slow-motion. To see more photos and videos, please visit me @ladzinski.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @acacia.johnson | On January 31 the EPA moved to conserve Alaska’s Bristol Bay under the Clean Water Act, protecting one of the world’s most productive wild salmon habitats from a proposed open-pit copper and gold mine called Pebble Mine. After decades of controversy over the mine, the decision is considered a win for the environment, for the bay’s salmon fishing industry, and the region’s many Alaska Native communities who depend on salmon for subsistence. It also means the brown bears of the Alaska Peninsula—which gather in the largest numbers seen anywhere on Earth—now have their habitat protected too. To celebrate, here’s some footage from the summer I spent documenting their story for @natgeo in 2019. #alaska #bristolbay #pebblemine #brownbears #environment #conservation #epsilon-alerts

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @chrisburkard | Sitting at the intersection of the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, Iceland is a hot spot for volcanic activity. With roughly one eruption every five years, the country was indeed "on schedule" in August 2022 with the Meradalir volcano on the Reykjanes Peninsula. The spewing lava made for an incredible display of nature's power. Read more from the story at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Video by @paulnicklen | Spending time in the company of the biggest animal in the history of the world, the blue whale, has a particularly humbling power over the human spirit. The fact that we share our planet with these ancient leviathans that can reach over 100 feet (30m) long is incredible on its own, but seeing them in person is an entirely different experience. Blue whales have reigned over the deep oceans for well over a million years, cycling critical nutrients across the world in their largely mysterious wanderings. 

Follow me @paulnicklen on my conservation journey to protect our ocean’s wildlife and their vulnerable ecosystems.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @javier_aznar_photography | I came upon this creepy scene in Ecuador’s Yasuni National Park. A nocturnal hunter, this wandering spider of the Ctenidae family targeted a dead katydid but also fed on a parasitic worm that was exiting the katydid. Two for the price of one. To find out more about these mesmerizing animals, see the March issue or go to the link in bio. Follow @javier_aznar_photography to learn more about spiders and other small creatures.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @jenniferhayesig | A near-term zebra shark embryo that began its life in an aquarium wriggles inside its egg case. This baby shark is part of a groundbreaking conservation effort called ReShark—an exciting program in which 44 partner aquariums source shark eggs that are flown to Indonesia to be raised at the Raja Ampat Research & Conservation Center on the island of Kri. After hatching, the young pups are cared for by marine biologists, affectionately called shark nannies. The pups live in special tanks and graduate to special sea pens where they learn to forage for their own prey. When they’re large enough to deter predators and pass a final health check, they’re released into patrolled marine protected areas where zebra sharks have vanished because of overfishing. ReShark is a growing global collaboration of 75 partners from 15 countries that have united to put sharks back where they belong. Read more about this story, “A Wild Plan,” in National Geographic’s July issue or at the link in bio. And follow @jenniferhayesig for more stories about the ocean and the creatures we share our planet with.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Photo by @joelsartore | Alaska's North Slope has a reputation for harboring clouds of fearless mosquitoes. I learned this the hard way while on assignment there for National Geographic in 2006.

Desperate after three days without taking a single good photo, I decided to turn the camera on myself. I took off my shoes and socks in a scenic place and let the mosquitos eat me alive for 20 or so minutes. They piled on so thick they made a crackling sound. Later, my feet itched so badly that I scratched them raw for three hours straight.

There were two silver linings to this experiment: This image became one of the most talked about photos of my career, and I was given a gift certificate for a pedicure from the magazine's director of photography. I still don’t think my feet looked that bad.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Video by @babaktafreshi | In California’s Pinnacles National Park, I was looking for big-eared bats—which can be heard with their clicking sounds—when a “train” of satellites photobombed the clip. The recently launched set are on the way to their final orbit, at about 550 kilometers out—part of the Starlink satellite constellation for network services. SpaceX has launched 4,000+ Starlink satellites, with about 12,000 total planned and a possible extension to 42,000.

The sky above us is becoming very busy. On one side is our need for internet access. More than 3 billion people still don’t have it. On the other side is the environmental impact of such mega constellations—and Starlink will not be the only one. Frequent rocket launches increase black carbon chemicals in the atmosphere, which could exacerbate climate change. Sunlight-reflecting satellites would impact astronomical research and the night sky experience. SpaceX has been in the process of adding shields and dark coating to satellites and changing their orientation to reduce visible reflection from the solar panels.

As they travel to their orbit, they’re visible for several weeks to the naked eye. Once in the final orbit, they’re usually too faint to see unaided. In telescope images, they can appear as bright streaks that ruin the result, though they can be removed through a time-consuming processing method.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
The last scientific record of a sperm whale birth was 1986, without audio or video. During a routine observation off Dominica in July, National Geographic Explorers and researchers from Project CETI came upon a remarkable event: the birth of a sperm whale. Because the team happened to be equipped with advanced technology, their data will likely reveal more than we’ve ever known about the species. Read more at the link in bio. @insidenatgeo @projectceti 

Host: @byallieyang 
Cover photo by @brianskerry

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Video by @jaimerojo | When millions of monarchs are flying around you in the forests of Michoacán, Mexico, it’s easy to think that their population is doing just fine. This “illusion of plenty” has haunted other species in the past. The IUCN’s decision to downlist monarchs from “endangered” to “vulnerable” raises many questions. Most scientists agree that habitat loss is behind the long-term decline of these butterflies. Although the numbers have been relatively stable in the past decade, they’re fluctuating around a much lower average. The new IUCN assessment is based on data from this past decade, but that doesn’t mean the monarchs are safe. They remain vulnerable to threats that include extreme weather events caused by climate change. In the end, many of us agree that we should keep doing what we can to conserve this species.

You can read more about the downlisting at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Video by @bertiegregory | A pod of wave-washing killer whales, or orcas, hunt three crabeater seals at once. There are only about a hundred of these special killer whales in Antarctica. We humans often wonder just how smart wild animals are. Well, these killer whales have learned that by using teamwork as a family group and water as a tool, they can create powerful waves to access seals that would otherwise be out of reach. Every single time we saw them hunt, their tactics were different and the types of waves they created were different. Their behavior was artful, not instinctive. This technique that they have mastered is like that of a professional athlete who masters a sport over decades of training. 

Watch these incredible hunters in "Animals Up Close with @bertiegregory," now streaming on @disneyplus. And learn more about them at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
Video by @jaimerojo | Monarch butterflies store enough fat prior to migrating that most of them do not need to eat much when they’re overwintering in Mexico, but they do need to drink, so water or dew must be available to them. To quench their thirst, hundreds swarm to the ground near a small stream in El Rosario Sanctuary, where they sip liquid and important minerals from the wet soil—a behavior called puddling. Butterflies don’t have a tongue; instead, they use a strawlike proboscis that can be stretched long and deep into flowers to feed on nectar or sip liquid but can be coiled up like a garden hose when not in use, to keep it safe and out of the way. The proboscis has taste receptors that help the butterfly determine if the nectar or sap is good to drink.

Learn more about monarchs at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title:
For meerkats in Africa’s Kalahari Desert, there’s strength in numbers 💪

#HostilePlanet is now streaming on @DisneyPlus.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @jenniferhayesig | A two-day-old harp seal, called a yellow coat, cries for its mother in the ice nursery near Québec’s Magdalen Islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Harp seals are born on sea ice typically in late February and nursed for 12 to 15 days before their mother leaves to mate and migrate north. Pups require weeks of stable ice to develop before they are mature enough to survive on their own. Rising air and sea temperatures in the past decade have resulted in unstable ice that collapses, causing catastrophic loss of pups. I began covering harp seals as a face of climate change in 2011, returning each year as conditions allowed. It is nearing pupping time. Imagine thousands of pregnant harp seals in the Gulf of St. Lawrence desperately searching for sea ice that has not formed. Read more about harp seals on thin ice at the link in bio.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Sofia may be a grandmother, but her age is no obstacle when it comes to providing for her family. She’s an adept hunter who’ll stop at nothing to feed those who depend on her. Narrated by @im.angelabassett, Queens, premieres tonight at 8/7c on @natgeotv. Stream on @DisneyPlus and @hulu.

post.author: natgeo
post.title: Video by @javier_aznar_photography | A darkling beetle eats a mushroom at night in Yasuní National Park, Ecuador.
